sen.j: 以津真天（いつまで/いつまでん）は、日本に伝わる妖怪の一種。
sen.e: Itsumade, or Itsumaden is one of monsters that have been handed down in Japan.
Itsumade, or Itsumaden is one of the monsters that have been handed down in Japan.
sen.cmt: one of→one of theとしました。
sen.e: Itsumade, or Itsumaden is one of the monsters that have been handed down in Japan.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 戦乱や飢餓などで死んだ死体をそのまま放っておくと、死体の近くに止まり、「いつまで、いつまで」と呪詛を込めて鳴き、死体を喰らう。
sen.e: If a dead body is left for a long time at the time of wars or famine, Itsumade perches close to the dead body croaking as if it cursed, `itsumade, itsumade' (until when) and eats the dead body.
If a dead body is left for a long time at the time of wars or famine, Itsumade perches close to the dead body croaking as if it cursed, 'itsumade, itsumade' (until when) and eats the dead body.

sen.j: この「いつまで」は、死体をいつまで放っておくのかという意味である。
sen.e: The word, `itsumade' means that until when the dead body will be left.

sen.j: 頭は鬼または人間で、身体は竜（またはヘビ）、歯や爪は鋭く身長は5メートルを超えているという。
sen.e: Itsumade' s head is the head of either Oni (ogre) or human being, its body is that of dragon (or snake), with sharp teeth and nails, and it is over five meters tall.

sen.j: それによれば建武 (日本)元年（1334年）の秋、毎晩のように紫宸殿の上に怪鳥が現れ「いつまでも、いつまでも」と鳴いて人々を恐れさせていた。
sen.e: According to the 広有射怪鳥事, in the autumn of 1334, an ominous bird came up over Shishin-den Hall (hall for state ceremonies) just about every night, croaking like `itsumademo, itsumademo' (until when), which scared people.
